questions.text: A young woman presents to the clinic with a history of a breast lump. On examination, the axillary lymph nodes are enlarged. The biopsy of the lump shows the presence of medullary carcinoma of the breast. Which of the following statement is true regarding the given condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Lymph nodes enlargement can be due to reactive hyperplasia

options.label: C
options.text: Majority of the tumours are triple positive

options.label: D
options.text: Has a poorer prognosis than invasive lobular carcinoma.

questions.correct_answer: A. Lymph nodes enlargement can be due to reactive hyperplasia
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Lymph nodes enlargement can be due to reactive hyperplasia Medullary carcinoma of the breast is associated with intense lymphocyte proliferation . Therefore, the lymph node enlargement can be due to reactive hyperplasia rather than the spread of cancer cells to the lymph nodes. Histopathology consists of the following: A dense lymphoreticular infiltration composed predominantly of lymphocytes and plasma cells. A sheet-like growth pattern of anaplastic cells with absent ductal or lobular differentiation. MANAGEMENT mainly involves procedures ( lumpectomy , simple mastectomy ) and radiation

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B. Medullary carcinoma of the breast is invasive ductal carcinoma and usually proliferates. However, it has a relatively better prognosis than other invasive breast cancers. Option: C. The majority of medullary carcinomas of the breast are triple-negative (ER, PR, HER-2-Neu negative). Option: D. Medullary carcinoma of the breast typically has a better prognosis than invasive ductal carcinoma or invasive lobular carcinoma despite the tumour's aggressiveness.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman comes to the physician for evaluation of a mass in the left breast that she first noticed 2 weeks ago. The mass has not increased during this period, and the patient has had no pain. Three months ago, she hit her left chest against the closet door, which was painful for a day. Menses occur at regular 28-day intervals and last 5 days with moderate flow. Her last menstrual period was 3 weeks ago. Physical examination shows dense breasts and a 2.5-cm well-defined, rubbery, mobile mass that is non-tender in the upper outer quadrant of the left breast. There is no axillary adenopathy. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Fibroadenoma A solid, painless, mobile mas s in a 29-year-old woman without any mastalgia, changes in the skin over the breast, or axillary lymphadenopathy indicates fibroadenoma , the most common breast tumour (although benign) in women < 35 years of age . Fibroadenomas should be closely monitored with clinical breast exams and imaging tests (ultrasounds and mammograms). Ultrasound-guided biopsy is indicated when lesions enlarge or have atypical imaging findings to rule out malignancy.

Highyeild:

Fibroadenoma is the most common benign tumour of the female breast, composed of both fibrous and glandular tissue . It is most commonly seen in young women between the ages of 15 to 30 years and is caused by increased sensitivity of focal areas of breast tissue to estrogen. Fibroadenoma is commonly known as " breast mouse. " Pathology : The tumour is an encapsulated spherical lesion that arises from the interlobular stroma, with stromal cells being either monoclonal or polyclonal. There are two types of fibroadenomas: pericanalicular (hard) and intracanalicular (soft) . The pericanalicular type is due to the proliferation of connective tissue inside the elastic lamina. In contrast, the intracanalicular type is due to the proliferation of connective tissue outside the elastic lamina. Clinical Features: Painless, slowly growing, solitary, mobile lump in the breast. Diagnosis : Fine needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) is the initial diagnostic test of choice. The presence of an antler horn configuration of ductal epidermal cells is highly suggestive of fibroadenoma . Popcorn calcification is seen on mammography . Treatment : No treatment is necessary when the diagnosis is confirmed. However, excision biopsy is the treatment for suspicious lesions and cosmetic indications.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Phyllodes tumour is generally large (average diameter of 4–7 cm), rapidly growing, and typically affects patients between 40–50 years of age . Also, patients with phyllodes tumours may notice an increase in the size of a breast mass a few weeks after discovering it. This 29-year-old woman lacks the symptoms of a phyllodes tumour, making it an unlikely diagnosis. Option: C. Although this patient reports a history of trauma to the breast, fat necrosis typically presents as an ill-defined, firm breast mass with an overlying area of skin thickening or retraction , which is inconsistent with this woman's well-defined, well-defined, rubbery breast lump. Option: D. Fibrocystic change of the breast is the most common benign lesion of the breast and typically presents with premenstrual breast pain that may be recurring or constant and unilateral or bilateral. On examination, areas of suspected growth tend to be diffuse as opposed to the focal, circumscribed mass found in this patient, making it an unlikely diagnosis.

Extraedge:

Mammography findings Popcorn calcification - fibroadenoma. Lead-pipe/egg-shell calcification - traumatic fat necrosis. Broken-needle type of calcification - duct ectasia. Tea-cup calcification - fibrocystic disease.

questions.text: A 41-year-old woman comes to the physician because of bleeding from the nipple of her right breast for 3 months. There is no bleeding from the other breast. Menses occur at regular 30-day intervals and last 5 days with moderate flow. Her last menstrual period was 1 week ago. Her mother died of breast cancer at the age of 53 years. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. She appears healthy. Her temperature is 37°C (98.7°F), her pulse is 76/min, and her blood pressure is 118/70 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and non-tender. Breast examination shows bleeding of the right breast on applying pressure with no palpable mass. The left breast shows no abnormalities. There is no palpable axillary lymphadenopathy. Pelvic examination shows a normal vagina and cervix. Ultrasonography shows a dilated duct enclosing a well-defined solitary mass. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Intraductal papilloma Solitary intraductal papillomas are typically present with unilateral bloody nipple discharge. Although a physical exam may reveal a palpable breast tumour close to or behind the nipple, intraductal papillomas may not be palpable, as in this patient. The absence of associated breast skin changes or axillary lymphadenopathy and the ultrasound finding of a dilated duct enclosing a well-defined solitary mass further support the diagnosis of this benign tumour.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Invasive ductal carcinoma may also present in perimenopausal women with bloody nipple discharge. However, it more commonly presents with a mass on palpation and ultrasound would show a poorly circumscribed mass with microcalcifications and disruption of tissue planes . Option: B. Patients with Paget's disease of the breast may present with bloody discharge from the nipple, but the nipple and areola would appear erythematous, fissured, cracked, and ulcerated. Ultrasonographic findings are usually nonspecific with heterogenous, hypoechoic regions, skin thickening, and dilated ducts. Option: C. Patients with papillary carcinoma of the breast may present with bloody discharge from the nipple and an intraductal mass on ultrasound . However, papillary carcinoma of the breast usually occurs in postmenopausal women , with a peak incidence in the seventh decade .

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of upper midthoracic back pain. The pain is severe, dull in quality, and worse during the night. Ten months ago, she underwent a modified radical mastectomy for invasive ductal carcinoma of the right breast. Physical examination shows normal muscle strength. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ in all extremities. Examination of the back shows tenderness over the thoracic spinous processes. An x-ray of the thoracic spine shows vertebral osteolytic lesions at T4 and T5. The patient's thoracic lesions are most likely a result of metastatic spread via which of the following structures?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Batson Venous Plexus This patient has metastatic lesions in the vertebrae. Metastases to bone are most commonly the result of hematogenous spread. The azygos vein receives blood from the right intercostal veins, which in turn receive blood from the right breast. The Azygos vein has numerous anastomoses with the vertebral venous plexus, a longitudinal network of valveless veins in the spine that includes the paravertebral plexus of Batson. The lack of valves in this network facilitates the spread of tumours and infections.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. The lateral axillary lymph nodes receive lymphatic drainage from the upper limb. They can be affected in patients with breast cancer if retrograde lymphatic flow and tumour spread occur due to obstruction of the central and apical axillary lymph nodes (upstream nodes) by tumor metastases. They are not a route for metastasis to the spine. Option: C. The thyrocervical trunk receives blood from the subclavian artery . It is a potential route for lung cancer metastasis to the scapula via the suprascapular branch or to the thyroid via the inferior thyroid artery. It is not a potential route for metastasis of breast cancer to the spine. Option: D. The anterior and posterior intercostal arteries are potential routes for metastasis of lung cancer to structures of the thoracic wall (e.g., ribs); they are not routes for metastasis of breast cancer .

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman comes to the physician to evaluate a right breast mass that she noticed 3 weeks ago. It has rapidly increased in size during this period. She does not have pain. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows large dense breasts; a 5-cm, non-tender, multinodular mass is palpated in the right outer quadrant of the right breast. There are no changes in the skin or nipple. There is no palpable cervical or axillary adenopathy. Mammography shows a smooth poly-lobulated mass. A biopsy of the mass shows papillary projections of epithelial-lined stroma with hyperplasia and atypia. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Phyllodes tumor It is a large (> 3 cm), rapidly growing (i.e., progression over days-weeks) breast mass that raises suspicion for phyllodes tumor. Phyllodes tumours are rare (< 1% of all breast tumortumours) and typically present as a painless breast lump, which can make differentiation from more common benign breast tumours (e.g., fibroadenoma) complex. Phyllodes tumours may even appear similar to fibroadenoma on imaging. Therefore, a biopsy is required to diagnose phyllodes tumour definitively; a biopsy shows a leaf-like appearance under the microscope .

Highyeild:

Phyllodes tumour is a rare (< 1% of all breast tumours), large(>3cm), rapidly growing, discrete and firm painless breast lump. They are usually benign, but most of them have malignant potential. They originate from the hormonally responsive stromal cells of the breast. Clinical features Large breast with the unevenly bosselated surface. Pressure necrosis may cause skin ulceration. They are mobile on the chest wall Primarily seen in 40–50 years (premenopausal) age. Phyllodes tumours are fibroepithelial tumours composed of epithelial and stromal components. Biopsy shows a leaf-like appearance under the microscope.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Intraductal papilloma causes single or multiple, sometimes palpable breast lesions associated with serous or bloody nipple discharge in 60–80% of cases. This patient's lack of discharge makes the diagnosis less likely. In addition, the biopsy findings rule out intraductal papilloma, which would show a central, branching, fibrovascular core with surrounding myoepithelial and epithelial cells. Option: C. Fibroadenoma is the most common breast tumor in women < 35 years old and usually presents as a solitary, non-tender, mobile mass , very similar to this patient's lesion. However, the fibroadenoma is less common in women > 35 years and typically has “popcorn” calcifications on mammography. A biopsy of fibroadenoma would show benign hyperplastic stroma encapsulating ductal tissue . Additionally, the rapid growth and size of this patient's tumor are not common features of fibroadenoma. Option: D. Invasive ductal carcinoma is the most common form of breast cancer and can present as a painless breast mass . Although malignancy should always be considered in patients with breast masses, especially in middle-aged women, invasive ductal carcinoma is more likely to appear with associated skin changes (retraction, dimpling, oedema), nipple retraction, and bloody nipple discharge. A benign mammogram and biopsy rule out this diagnosis.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman at 17 weeks gestation comes to the physician to evaluate a painless mass in the right breast for the last 3 weeks that has not increased in size. Physical examination shows dense breasts and a 2.5 cm rubbery, mobile mass that is non-tender in the upper outer quadrant of the right breast. A biopsy of the mass shows a rounded contour with overgrowth of fibrous and glandular tissue. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Fibroadenoma A solid, painless, mobile mass in a 33-year-old pregnant woman without any mastalgia, changes in the skin over the breast, or axillary lymphadenopathy indicates fibroadenoma , the most common breast tumor (although benign) in women < 35 years of age. This pregnant patient's elevated oestrogen levels have likely contributed to the mass appearance. A biopsy showing overgrowth of fibrous and glandular tissue confirms the diagnosis.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B. Breasts increase in size and may be tender during pregnancy , but masses are not normal and should be evaluated further. However, hormone-responsive masses can increase in size during pregnancy. Option: C. Fibrocystic breast change is the most common benign lesion of the breast and typically presents with premenstrual breast pain that may be recurring or constant and unilateral or bilateral. On exam, areas of suspected growth tend to be diffuse as opposed to the focal, circumscribed mass found in this patient, making it an unlikely diagnosis. Biopsy findings include stromal fibrosis, cysts, papillary apocrine changes, and mild epithelial hyperplasia or calcifications. Option: D. Unlike in this patient, phyllodes tumors are generally large (average diameter of 4–7 cm), proliferate, and typically affect patients between 40–50 years of age. Also, patients with phyllodes tumor may notice an increase in the size of a breast mass a few weeks after discovering it. A biopsy would show leaf-like architecture with a papillary projection of epithelium-lined stroma.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman comes to the physician for a 3-month history of bloody discharge from the right nipple. Her mother died of breast cancer at the age of 69 years. Mammography 6 months ago did not show any abnormalities. Examination of the breast shows an expression of a small amount of serosanguinous fluid from the right nipple; there are no palpable breast masses or axillary lymphadenopathy. Ultrasonography of the right breast shows a single dilated duct. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Intraductal papilloma A unilateral serosanguinous nipple discharge in a premenopausal patient with a single dilated duct highly suggests an intraductal papilloma. Physical exam findings may reveal a palpable breast tumor close to the nipple. However, in most cases, intraductal papillomas are not palpable, as in this patient. These lesions are typically benign but pose a slightly increased risk of cancer , thus necessitating a core needle biopsy.

Highyeild:

The most common cause of bloody nipple discharge is Intraductal papilloma. Duct ectasia is the most common cause of nipple discharge in a non-lactating woman.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Invasive ductal carcinoma may manifest with bloody nipple discharge in perimenopausal women , as seen here. However, the most common manifestation is a palpable rock-hard mass with distinct margins. Mammography of affected individuals characteristically shows clustered microcalcifications, whereas this patient had a normal mammogram. The patient's age, the subacute onset of unilateral bloody nipple discharge, and the reassuring mammogram suggest another diagnosis. Option: B. Paget disease of the breast is most commonly seen in patients > 50 years old who are also suffering from ductal carcinoma in situ. Physical exam findings would show an erythematous and fissured areola with or without a nipple discharge. This patient's age, serosanguinous nipple discharge, and absence of cutaneous findings are inconsistent with this diagnosis. Option: C. Phyllodes tumor is a fibroepithelial breast tumor often arising in the 5th decade of life. Physical examination most commonly shows a large mass with well-defined margins deep into the breast skin without nipple discharge. On ultrasonography , distinct hypoechoic cystic regions are seen. Mammography often shows spiculated masses devoid of calcification . This patient's subacute onset of unilateral nipple discharge, absence of palpable breast mass, and relatively young age make Phyllodes tumor unlikely.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman comes to the physician to evaluate a left breast mass she noticed 4 weeks ago. It has rapidly increased in size during this period. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows large dense breasts; a 6-cm, non-tender, multinodular mass is palpated in the upper outer quadrant of the left breast. There are no changes in the skin or nipple. There is no palpable cervical or axillary adenopathy. Mammography shows a smooth poly-lobulated mass. A photomicrograph of a biopsy specimen is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Phyllodes tumor This 48-year-old woman has a rapidly growing 6 cm breast mass without mastalgia, skin/nipple changes, or lymphadenopathy, indicating a benign condition . The mammogram also suggests a benign condition (no spiculation or microcalcifications). A large (> 3 cm), rapidly growing (i.e., progression over days-weeks) breast mass raises suspicion of phyllodes tumor. Phyllodes tumor is rare (< 1% of all breast tumors) and typically presents as a painless breast lump, which can make differentiation from more common benign breast tumor (e.g., fibroadenoma) difficult. Phyllodes tumor may even appear similar to fibroadenoma on imaging. Therefore, a biopsy is required to definitively diagnose phyllodes tumor ; a biopsy shows a leaf-like appearance under the microscope.

Highyeild:

Phyllodes tumor is a rare (< 1% of all breast tumors), large(>3cm), rapidly growing, discrete and firm painless breast lump. They are usually benign, but most of them have malignant potential. They originate from the hormonally responsive stromal cells of the breast. Clinical features Large breast with the unevenly bosselated surface. Pressure necrosis may cause skin ulceration. They are mobile on the chest wall Primarily seen in 40–50 years (premenopausal) age. Phyllodes tumours are fibroepithelial tumours composed of epithelial and stromal components. Biopsy shows a leaf-like appearance under the microscope.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Fibrocystic breast disease is the most common benign breast condition and commonly causes a palpable breast mass . However, fibrocystic breast lesions are typically associated with mastalgia, cyclic pain with menses, and clear/white nipple discharge , none of which are present in this case. On mammograms , the fibrocystic disease would typically show focal regions of thick parenchyma and/or cysts. In addition, the fibrocystic disease is not associated with a leaf-like appearance and papillary projections on biopsy. Option: B. Fibroadenoma is the most common breast tumor in women < 35 years old and usually presents as a solitary, non-tender, mobile mass, very similar to this patient's lesion. However, the fibroadenoma is less common in women > 35 years and typically has “popcorn” calcifications on mammography . A biopsy of fibroadenoma would show benign hyperplastic stroma encapsulating ductal tissue . In addition, the rapid growth and size of this patient's tumor are not common features of fibroadenoma. Option: D. Intraductal papilloma causes single or multiple, sometimes palpable breast lesions that are associated with serous or bloody nipple discharge in 60–80% of cases. This patient's lack of discharge makes the diagnosis less likely. In addition, the biopsy findings rule out intraductal papilloma, which would show a central, branching, fibrovascular core with surrounding myoepithelial and epithelial cells.

questions.text: A 93-year-old woman is brought to the physician because of a purple area on her right arm growing for one month. She has not had any pain or itching in the area. She has hyperlipidaemia, a history of basal cell carcinoma treated with Mohs surgery 2 years ago, and a history of invasive ductal carcinoma of the right breast treated with radical mastectomy 57 years ago. She has had chronic lymphedema of the right upper extremity since the mastectomy. Her only medication is simvastatin. She lives in an assisted living facility. She is content with her living arrangement but feels guilty that she is dependent on others. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows extensive edema of the right arm. Skin exam of the proximal upper right extremity shows three coalescing, 0.5–1.0 cm heterogeneous, purple-coloured plaques with associated ulceration. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Lymphangiosarcoma Lymphangiosarcoma is a rare, secondary malignancy that originates in vascular endothelial cells and occurs secondary to chronic lymphedema, classically in women who have undergone axillary lymphadenectomy after mastectomy. It typically presents as multiple purple-coloured macules and/or papules and can also present with tender, subcutaneous nodules.

Highyeild:

Stewart-Treves Syndrome Stewart-Treves Syndrome is lymphangiosarcoma of the upper extremity in women who have undergone radical mastectomy and have ipsilateral lymphedema. On average, the interval between mastectomy and the development of angiosarcoma is around 5 years. In 60% of women , the development of this cancer is associated with a history of adjuvant radiation therapy. Clinical features include acute worsening of edema, and the appearance of subcutaneous nodules with a tendency towards haemorrhage and ulceration. The treatment approach involves preoperative chemotherapy and radiotherapy followed by surgical excision, typically with a radical amputation. This condition is associated with a poor prognosis.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B. Thrombophlebitis of a superficial vein typically presents with erythema and tenderness along the vein and can cause congestion of venous vasculature distal to the thrombus. In the upper extremities, it is usually associated with intravenous catheter use. While the distribution of this patient's lesions could potentially fit with thrombophlebitis, she does not have the associated pain and erythema that would be expected. Her history of chronic lymphedema suggests a different diagnosis. Option: C. Elder abuse should always be considered in an elderly patient presenting with possible bruises or hematomas. However, the chronicity, progressive growth in size, and history of lymphedema make an alternative diagnosis more likely. Option: D. Kaposi sarcoma may also present with purple-coloured skin plaques of the extremities that can progress to deeper, more nodular, and, occasionally, ulcerative lesions. However, the lesions occur in patients with significantly immunocompromised status (e.g., AIDS, transplant recipients). The absence of severe immuno- compromise in this elderly woman makes this diagnosis highly unlikely, and her history suggests an alternative diagnosis.

questions.text: Lesions with malignant potential include all of the following EXCEPT:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Sclerosing adenosis Sclerosing adenosis is prevalent during the childbearing and perimenopausal years and has no malignant potential.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Intraductal Papillomatosis , which can be associated with nipple discharge , are susceptible to malignant transformation. Option: B. Individuals diagnosed with atypical ductal hyperplasia (ADH ) are at increased risk or development of breast cancer and should be counselled appropriately regarding risk reduction strategies. Option: D: Atypical lobular hyperplasia (ALH) results in minimal distention of lobular units with cells similar to those seen in lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS).

questions.text: A 45-year-old female is referred to the breast clinic with a smooth, firm, well-circumscribed lump that has grown rapidly in the last 2 weeks. Ultrasound imaging of the lump reveals a smooth, encapsulated 7-cm lump from which core biopsies are taken. The biopsy results confirm a fibroepithelial tumour consisting of epithelial cells and spindle cell stroma. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Phyllodes tumour Phyllodes tumours are fibroepithelial tumours composed of epithelial and stromal components. They are usually benign, but about 25% are malignant and metastasise. As even the benign forms have malignant potential, all phyllodes tumours are considered breast cancer. They usually present between the ages of 40 and 50 (premenopausal) as fast-growing, discrete, firm masses that may be difficult to distinguish from fibroadenomas. In patients under the age of 25 years, FNA may be relied upon; if over 25 years or if doubt remains, core biopsy or excision biopsy may be used to confirm the diagnosis.

Highyeild:

Phyllodes tumor is a rare (< 1% of all breast tumors), large(>3cm), rapidly growing, discrete and firm painless breast lump. They are usually benign, but most of them have malignant potential. They originate from the hormonally responsive stromal cells of the breast. Clinical features Large breast with the unevenly bosselated surface. Pressure necrosis may cause skin ulceration. They are mobile on the chest wall Primarily seen in 40–50 years (premenopausal) age. Phyllodes tumours are fibroepithelial tumours composed of epithelial and stromal components. Biopsy shows a leaf-like appearance under the microscope.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Fibrocystic breast disease is the most common benign breast condition and commonly causes a palpable breast mass. However, fibrocystic breast lesions are typically associated with mastalgia, cyclic pain with menses, and clear/white nipple discharge, none of which are present in this case. Option: B. Intraductal papilloma causes single or multiple, sometimes palpable breast lesions that are associated with serous or bloody nipple discharge in 60–80% of cases. This patient's lack of discharge makes the diagnosis less likely. In addition, the biopsy findings rule out intraductal papilloma, which would show a central, branching, fibrovascular core with surrounding myoepithelial and epithelial cells. Option: C. Fibroadenoma is the most common breast tumortumour in women < 35 years old and usually presents as a solitary, non-tender, mobile mass. However, the fibroadenoma is less common in women > 35 years. A biopsy of fibroadenoma would show benign hyperplastic stroma encapsulating ductal tissue. In addition, the rapid growth and size of this patient's tumortumour are not common features of fibroadenoma.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman feels a lump in her right breast. She has normal menstrual cycles, is G3P3, and her last child was born 5 years ago. On examination, a 2 cm, irregular, firm area is palpated beneath the lateral edge of the areola. This lumpy area is not painful and is movable. There are no lesions of the overlying skin and no axillary lymphadenopathy. A biopsy specimen shows microscopic evidence of increased dilated ducts surrounded by fibrous connective tissue. Fluid-filled ducts with apocrine metaplasia also are present. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Fibrocystic changes Non-proliferative (fibrocystic) changes account for the largest category of breast lumps. These lesions are probably related to cyclic breast changes that occur during the menstrual cycle. In about 30% of cases of breast lumps, no specific pathologic diagnosis can be made. Fibrocystic changes include ductal proliferation, ductal dilation (sometimes with apocrine metaplasia), and Fibrosis.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. A fibroadenoma is a discrete mass formed by a proliferation of fibrous stroma with compressed ductules. Option: C. Infiltrating ductal carcinomas have proliferations of atypical neoplastic cells that fill ducts and can invade stroma. Option: D. Inspissated duct secretions may produce duct ectasia with a surrounding lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate .

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman has noticed a bloody discharge from the nipple of her left breast for the past 3 days. On physical examination, the skin of the breasts appears normal, and no masses are palpable. There is no axillary lymphadenopathy. She has regular menstrual cycles and is using oral contraceptives. Excisional biopsy is most likely to show which of the following lesions in her left breast?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Intraductal papilloma Intraductal papillomas are usually solitary and smaller than 1 cm. They are located in large lactiferous sinuses or large ducts and tend to bleed , though they are benign .

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Abscesses complicating mastitis organise with a fibrous wall. Option: B. Fibroadenomas contain ducts with stroma and are not highly vascular; these lesions are not located in ducts. Option: D. Phyllodes tumor also arise from the intralobular stroma and can be malignant, but they do not invade ducts to cause bleeding.

questions.text: A 48-year-old lady with central invasive breast cancer underwent a mastectomy and axillary clearance of level I and II nodes. On the postoperative ward round, she complained of numbness in the medial aspect of the upper arm. Which nerve is most likely damaged to cause the described symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Intercostobrachial nerve Patients should be warned explicitly of neurovascular damage before surgery. In particular, they should consent to possible numbness on the medial aspect of the upper arm, which is supplied by the intercostobrachial nerve .

Highyeild:

Nerve injuries Intercostobrachial nerve - Numbness on the medial aspect of the upper arm. Long thoracic nerve - Winging of the scapula. Axillary nerve - Regimental badge anaesthesia.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B. The long thoracic nerve supplies the serratus anterior muscle ; damage to this will result in winging of the scapula. Option: C. Thoracodorsal nerve innervates the latissimus dorsi muscle and should be preserved, particularly in those undergoing latissimus dorsi flap reconstructions. Option: D. Axillary nerve supplies the deltoid and teres minor muscles and the small patch of skin on the lateral aspect of the upper arm, called the ‘regimental badge patch’.

questions.text: A 42-year-old nulligravida woman comes to the clinic with intermittent blood from her left nipple. She is extremely worried because her 66-year-old mother was recently diagnosed with breast cancer. The patient performs monthly breast self-examinations and has not felt any lumps. She has a history of type 2 diabetes, for which she takes insulin and metformin. The patient does not smoke cigarettes and only drinks alcohol on rare social occasions. Physical examination shows no palpable breast masses. Mammography shows no masses or calcifications. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Intraductal papilloma Pathologic nipple discharge is typically unilateral, bloody, or serous and may be accompanied by additional breast abnormalities. Intraductal papilloma is the most common cause of unilateral bloody discharge without a coexisting breast mass . Typically, this benign condition is nonpalpable on clinical breast examination due to the small size of the papilloma inside the duct. Although this patient's family history of breast cancer increases her risk of breast malignancy, normal examination and negative imaging findings are reassuring and confirm the diagnosis. Diagnostic workup for pathologic (e.g., unilateral and/or bloody) nipple discharge should begin with mammography to rule out carcinoma without a palpable breast mass. With small intraductal papillomas, mammography is often normal . Ultrasound is also indicated for evaluation of ductal pathology and may demonstrate a dilated duct due to the space-occupying papilloma.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Although intraductal papillomas may contain foci of ductal carcinoma in situ, this condition typically presents as microcalcifications on mammography , which are absent in this patient Option: B. Fibrocystic breast changes are very common in premenopausal patients. The classic presentation is a patient with cyclic bilateral breast pain (e.g., mastalgia) and diffuses nodularity on breast examination. Nipple discharge is not typical but, if present, is non-bloody (e.g., physiologic). This condition is unlikely in this patient without palpable breast masses and mastalgia. Option: D. Paget disease of the breast is a form of ductal carcinoma that primarily presents with eczematous nipple changes (e.g., flaking, crusting skin) that also include the areola. This condition can also have bloody nipple discharge but is unlikely in this patient without skin or nipple changes in normal mammography.

questions.text: Which among the following statements concerning pathologies of the breast is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: A breast cyst is considered to be an aberration of normal development and involution

options.label: B
options.text: Early menopause is a risk factor for the development of breast cancer

options.label: C
options.text: Invasive ductal carcinoma accounts for 20% of breast cancers

options.label: D
options.text: The nipple-areolar complex is spared when undertaking a simple mastectomy procedure

questions.correct_answer: A. A breast cyst is considered to be an aberration of normal development and involution
questions.explanation:
Solution:

A breast cyst is considered to be an aberration of normal development and involution Breast cysts are among the most frequent reasons for referral to the breast clinic. They are considered an aberration of normal development and involution (ANDI). It occurs due to a non-integrated involution of stroma and epithelium (When the stroma involutes too quickly, alveoli remain and form microcysts, precursors of macrocysts). Breast cysts are classically seen in perimenopausal women, although they may be seen on hormone replacement therapy in younger or older women .

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman comes to the office for a breast cancer follow-up visit. The patient recently underwent a right mastectomy for a node-negative, oestrogen- and progesterone-receptor-positive tumour. She was started on an aromatase inhibitor for adjuvant therapy; however, the medication was discontinued due to severe fatigue and poor sleep. As a result, she is scheduled to begin a 5-year course of adjuvant therapy with tamoxifen. The patient has no other chronic medical conditions, and her only medication is a daily multivitamin. Her last menstrual period was 5 years ago. This patient's father had a myocardial infarction at age 65; family history is otherwise non-contributory. She does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs. Vital signs are stable. BMI is 21 kg/m². The patient has many concerns about tamoxifen therapy and asks about potential side effects. Which of the following is the patient at greatest risk for developing due to tamoxifen therapy?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hyperplasia of endometrium Adjuvant endocrine therapy is commonly used for the treatment of nonmetastatic, hormone-receptor-positive breast cancer. The most commonly used endocrine agents include tamoxifen, aromatase inhibitors , and ovarian suppression (e.g., GnRH agonists or surgery). Tamoxifen is a selective oestrogen receptor modulator that is an oestrogen receptor antagonist in the breast . It is the preferred adjuvant treatment for premenopausal women at low risk of breast cancer recurrence. Tamoxifen is also a second-line endocrine adjuvant agent for postmenopausal women who cannot use aromatase inhibitor therapy (e.g., intolerable side effects) Tamoxifen acts as an oestrogen agonist in the uterus that can stimulate excessive endometrial proliferation. Therefore, tamoxifen use is associated with endometrial polyps in premenopausal women as well as endometrial hyperplasia and cancer in postmenopausal women. These risks continue for the duration of therapy and resolve after discontinuation of treatment. However, the benefit of improved survival from breast cancer due to tamoxifen outweighs the risk of endometrial cancer.

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. In postmenopausal women , tamoxifen has some oestrogen-like activity on the bone , which can increase bone mineral density and significantly reduce the incidence of osteoporosis. However, tamoxifen is generally not a first-line agent for osteoporosis treatment due to the risk of endometrial cancer. Option: B. Dysplasia of the cervical transformation zone is typically caused by chronic human papillomavirus infection. Tamoxifen has no known effects on the cervix. Option: D. Intimal thickening of the coronary arteries is a precursor lesion for atherosclerosis. Tamoxifen decreases the blood cholesterol level and may protect against coronary artery disease .

questions.correct_answer: D. The average age at diagnosis is 65 to 70 years
questions.explanation:
Solution:

The average age at diagnosis is 65 to 70 years Lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS) The average age at diagnosis is 45 years , which is approximately 15 to 25 years younger than the age at diagnosis of invasive breast cancer. LCIS originates from the terminal duct lobular units and develops only in the female breast. (because lobules are absent in the breast of males) Cytoplasmic mucoid globules are a distinctive cellular feature. The frequency of LCIS in the general population cannot be reliably determined because it usually presents as an incidental finding.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman, gravida 3 para 3, comes to the clinic due to left breast swelling and pain that has worsened over the past month. The patient weaned her youngest child from breastfeeding approximately 2 months ago. She last saw a healthcare provider a month ago for mastitis and was prescribed antibiotics. Her BMI is 46.6 kg/m², her Temperature is 37.6 C (99.7 F), and her blood pressure is 110/68 mm Hg. Physical examination reveals a morbidly obese woman in no apparent distress. Breast examination shows a left breast that is diffusely warm and erythematous with some dimpling. The right breast appears normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Inflammatory breast carcinoma This patient's clinical features are most likely due to inflammatory breast carcinoma (IBC). This rare but aggressive cancer classically presents as rapid-onset oedematous cutaneous thickening with a "peau d'orange" appearance (e.g., superficial dimpling, fine pitting). The affected breast is oedematous, erythematous, and painful. Itching, a palpable breast mass, and nipple changes (e.g., flattening/retraction) may also be present. Patients commonly have axillary lymphadenopathy suggesting metastatic disease. The next step in the evaluation should include mammography and ultrasound. A tissue biopsy is necessary to confirm the diagnosis.

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A & D. Clinically, IBC can be confused with an infectious process (e.g., mastitis, abscess) due to the common symptoms of warmth, pain, and erythema However, infection typically is accompanied by fever and improves with antibiotic treatment. In addition, the peau d'orange findings make infection unlikely. Option: B. Infiltrating ductal carcinoma may cause dimpling or breast contour changes. In contrast to IBC, diffuse breast erythema, oedema, and peau d'orange appearance are absent in other types of breast cancer.
